_comment: This data is an early work-in-progress and contains errors. Produced by @michaelh at Discuss and Discover SuttaCentral forum - please get in touch! Finished code forthcoming.

The five aggregates that a mendicant tru: Any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all form
Any kind of feeling at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all feeling
Any kind of perception at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all perception
Any kind of choices at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all choices
Any kind of consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near, all consciousness
Four noble truths that a mendicant truly: This is the origin of suffering
This is the cessation of suffering
This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering
